member.summary: Provides outgoing messages for , given random arguments to the function.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.MatrixMultiplyOp.AverageLogFactor
member.summary: Evidence message for VMP
member.returns: Zero

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(factor(matrixMultiply,A,B)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for VMP.

member.summary: VMP message to 'matrixMultiply'
member.param: Incoming message from 'A'. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from 'B'. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'matrixMultiply' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[sum_(A,B) p(A,B) factor(matrixMultiply,A,B)].

member.summary: VMP message to 'matrixMultiply'
member.param: Incoming message from 'B'. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'matrixMultiply' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[sum_(B) p(B) factor(matrixMultiply,A,B)].

member.summary: VMP message to 'matrixMultiply'
member.param: Incoming message from 'A'. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'matrixMultiply' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[sum_(A) p(A) factor(matrixMultiply,A,B)].

member.summary: VMP message to 'A'
member.param: Incoming message from 'matrixMultiply'. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from 'B'. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'A' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'A'. Because the factor is deterministic, 'matrixMultiply' is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(B) p(B) log(sum_matrixMultiply p(matrixMultiply) factor(matrixMultiply,A,B))).

member.summary: VMP message to 'A'
member.param: Incoming message from 'matrixMultiply'. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.

member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'A' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of 'A' with 'matrixMultiply' integrated out. The formula is sum_matrixMultiply p(matrixMultiply) factor(matrixMultiply,A,B).

member.summary: VMP message to 'a'
member.param: Incoming message from 'innerProduct'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from 'b'. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'a'. Because the factor is deterministic, 'innerProduct' is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(b) p(b) log(sum_innerProduct p(innerProduct) factor(innerProduct,a,b))).

member.param: Incoming message from 'X'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.

Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'B'. Because the factor is deterministic, 'X' is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(A) p(A) log(sum_X p(X) factor(X,A,B))).

member.summary: VMP message to 'X'
member.param: Incoming message from 'A'. Must be a proper distribution. If all elements are uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from 'B'. Must be a proper distribution. If all elements are uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'X' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[sum_(A,B) p(A,B) factor(X,A,B)].

member.summary: How much damping to use to prevent improper messages.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.ProductGaussianBetaVmpOp.ProductAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Beta)
member.summary: VMP message to 'product'
member.param: Incoming message from 'a'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from 'b'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'product' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[sum_(a,b) p(a,b) factor(product,a,b)].

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.ProductGaussianBetaVmpOp.ProductAverageLogarithm(System.Double,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Beta)
member.summary: VMP message to 'product'

Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'product' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[sum_(b) p(b) factor(product,a,b)].

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.ProductGaussianBetaVmpOp.AAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Beta)
member.summary: VMP message to 'a'
member.param: Incoming message from 'product'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from 'b'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'a'. Because the factor is deterministic, 'product' is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(b) p(b) log(sum_product p(product) factor(product,a,b))).

members.member:
Evidence message for VMP
Message from copy Message from value Message to value In Variational Message Passing, the evidence contribution of a deterministic factor is zero. Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for VMP. This factor is implicitly maintaining the truncated Gaussian variational posterior. Therefore we need to remove the entropy of the Gaussian representation, and add the entropy for the truncated Gaussian Evidence

Incoming message from 'mean'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'precision' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'precision'. The formula is exp(sum_(sample,mean) p(sample,mean) log(factor(sample,mean,precision))).

member.summary: Evidence message for VMP

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BernoulliFromLogOddsOp.LogOddsAverageLogarithm(System.Boolean,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian)
member.summary: Gradient matching VMP message from factor to logOdds variable
member.param: Incoming message. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Previous message sent, used for damping
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the Gaussian approximation to the factor which results in the same derivatives of the KL(q||p) divergence with respect to the parameters of the posterior as if the true factor had been used.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.AllTrueOp.AllTrueAverageConditional(System.Collections.Generic.IList{MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli})
member.summary: EP message to 'allTrue'.
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the 'allTrue' argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'allTrue' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(allTrue) sum_(array) p(array) factor(allTrue,array)]/p(allTrue).

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of 'allTrue' conditioned on the given values.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian
member.summary: Represents a one-dimensional Gaussian distribution.

remarks.para: The distribution is represented by two parameters: MeanTimesPrecision and Precision. Precision is the inverse of the variance, so a Gaussian with mean m and variance v is represented as Precision = 1/v, MeanTimesPrecision = m/v.

Some special cases: If the Precision is zero, then the distribution is uniform. If the Precision is infinite, then the distribution is a point mass. The Point property gives the location of the point mass.

The formula for the distribution is: N(x;m,v) = 1/sqrt(2*pi*v) * exp(-(x-m)^2/(2v)). When v=0, this reduces to delta(x-m). When v=infinity, the density is redefined to be 1. When v < 0, the density is redefined to be exp(-0.5*x^2*(1/v) + x*(m/v)), i.e. we drop the terms exp(-m^2/(2v))/sqrt(2*pi*v).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian.GetLogAverageOf(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian)
member.summary: Gets the integral of the product of two Gaussians.
member.remarks: this = N(x;m1,v1). that = N(x;m2,v2). int_(-infinity)^(infinity) N(x;m1,v1) N(x;m2,v2) dx = N(m1; m2, v1+v2). When improper, the density is redefined to be exp(-0.5*x^2*(1/v) + x*(m/v)), i.e. we drop the terms exp(-m^2/(2v))/sqrt(2*pi*v).
member.returns: log(N(m1;m2,v1+v2)).

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.IGeneratedAlgorithm
member.summary: Interface for running a generated inference algorithm

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.IGeneratedAlgorithm.Execute(System.Int32)
member.summary: Execute the inference algorithm for the specified number of iterations, starting from the initial state
member.param: The number of iterations to perform from the initial state
member.remarks: Sets NumberOfIterationsDone = . This method is equivalent to calling Reset() followed by Update(numberOfIterations).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.IGeneratedAlgorithm.Update(System.Int32)
member.summary: Perform additional iterations of the inference algorithm
member.param: The number of additional iterations to perform
member.remarks: If no observed values have changed, this method increments NumberOfIterationsDone by , and is equivalent to calling Execute(NumberOfIterationsDone + additionalIterations). If some observed values have changed, this method sets NumberOfIterationsDone = , and is not equivalent to calling Execute, because it will start from the existing message state rather than the initial state.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.IGeneratedAlgorithm.Reset
member.summary: Reset all messages to their initial values. Sets NumberOfIterationsDone to 0
member.remarks: This method is equivalent to calling Execute(0)

member.param: Name of the variable in the generated code
member.returns: The marginal distribution computed up to this point
member.remarks: Execute, Update, or Reset must be called first to set the value of the marginal.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'a'. members.member:
Estimates a Wishart distribution from samples.
The distribution is estimated via moment matching (not maximum-likelihood). E[X] = (a+(d+1)/2)/B var(X_ii) = (a+(d+1)/2)*diag(inv(B))^2 because X_ii ~ Gamma(a+(d+1)/2, 1/diag(inv(B))). Therefore: a = E[X_ii]^2/var(X_ii) - (d+1)/2 B = (a+(d+1)/2)/E[X]
In the one-dimensional case, E[log(x)] = -log(b) + digamma(a+1) =approx -log(b) + log(a+1) - 1/2/(a+1) = log(E[x]) - 1/2/(a+1) In the Wishart case, E[logdet(X)] = -logdet(B) + sum_{i=0..d-1} digamma(a + (d+1-i)/2) =approx -logdet(B) + d*digamma(a+(d+1)/2) =approx -logdet(B) + d*log(a+(d+1)/2) - d/2/(a+(d+1)/2) = log(E[X}) - d/2/(a+(d+1)/2)

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Collections.FileArray`1
member.summary: An IArray where each element is stored as a disk file.

remarks.para: The elements (whose values do not equal default(T)) are stored as individual files in a temp folder. Elements equal to default(T) are not stored. A FileArray may contain FileArrays as elements: these are called child FileArrays. Child FileArrays must be created using the special constructor. When a FileArray (that is not a child) is Disposed or garbage collected, the folder is deleted. A child FileArray is deleted only when its parent is deleted. Thus if the program exits normally, all temp folders should be deleted. However, if the program halts with an exception, temp folders will not be deleted and must be cleaned up manually.

Be careful when modifying elements of the FileArray in place. If fa is a FileArray, then the syntax fa[i][j] = 0; or fa[i].property = 0; will not have any effect. This happens because fa[i] reads the element from disk but does not write it back again. You must explicitly read the element, modify it, then write it back like so: T item = fa[i]; item.property=0; fa[i] = item;

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.SparseVector.MaxDiff(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector)
member.summary: Returns the maximum absolute difference between this vector and another vector.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.SparseVector.MaxDiff(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the maximum relative difference between this vector and another.
member.param: An offset to avoid division by zero.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])/(abs(this[i]) + rel)). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.SparseVector.PredivideBy(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.UpperTriangularMatrix)
member.summary: Gets the solution to Ax=b, where A is an upper triangular matrix, and b is this vector. Equivalent to the left-division x = A\b.
member.remarks: this is used as the right-hand side vector b, and it also receives the solution. It is not recommended to call this on a sparse vector, because the result will not be sparse in general. Throws an exception if is singular.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.SparseVector.PredivideByTranspose(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.LowerTriangularMatrix)
member.summary: Gets the solution to A'x=b, where A is a lower triangular matrix, and b is this vector. Equivalent to the left-division x = A'\b.
member.remarks: this is used as the right-hand side vector b, and it also receives the solution. It is not recommended to call this on a sparse vector, because the result will not be sparse in general. Throws an exception if is singular.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.SparseVector.PredivideBy(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.LowerTriangularMatrix)
member.summary: Gets the solution to Ax=b, where A is a lower triangular matrix, and b is this vector. Equivalent to the left-division x = A\b.
member.remarks: this is used as the right-hand side vector b, and it also receives the solution. It is not recommended to call this on a sparse vector, because the result will not be sparse in general. Throws an exception if is singular.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.SparseVector.PredivideBy(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.PositiveDefiniteMatrix)
member.summary: Premultiply this vector by the inverse of the given positive definite matrix
member.remarks: this is used as the right-hand side vector b, and it also receives the solution. It is not recommended to call this on a sparse vector, because the result will not be sparse in general.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.ApproximateSparseVector.MaxDiff(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector)
member.summary: Returns the maximum absolute difference between this vector and another vector.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.ApproximateSparseVector.MaxDiff(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the maximum relative difference between this vector and another.
member.param: An offset to avoid division by zero.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])/(abs(this[i]) + rel)). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.FastSumOp
member.summary: Provides outgoing messages for , given random arguments to the function.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.FastSumOp.LogAverageFactor(System.Double,System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(factor(sum,array)).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.FastSumOp.LogEvidenceRatio(System.Double,System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(factor(sum,array)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.FastSumOp.AverageLogFactor(System.Double,System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Evidence message for VMP
member.returns: Zero

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(factor(sum,array)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for VMP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.FastSumOp.LogAverageFactor(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.param: Incoming message from 'sum'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(sum) p(sum) factor(sum,array)).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.FastSumOp.LogAverageFactor(System.Double,System.Collections.Generic.IList{MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian})
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.param: Incoming message from 'array'. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(array) p(array) factor(sum,array)).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.FastSumOp.LogEvidenceRatio(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(sum) p(sum) factor(sum,array) / sum_sum p(sum) messageTo(sum)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.FastSumOp.LogEvidenceRatio(System.Double,System.Collections.Generic.IList{MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian})
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(array) p(array) factor(sum,array)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.FastSumOp.SumAverageConditional(System.Collections.Generic.IList{MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian})
member.summary: EP message to 'sum'
member.param: Incoming message from 'array'. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the 'sum' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'sum' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(sum) sum_(array) p(array) factor(sum,array)]/p(sum).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.FastSumOp.ArrayAverageConditional``1(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,System.Collections.Generic.IList{MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian},``0)
member.summary: EP message to 'array'
member.param: Incoming message from 'sum'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'array' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(array) sum_(sum) p(sum) factor(sum,array)]/p(array).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.FastSumOp.ArrayAverageConditional(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian[],MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian[])
member.summary: EP message to 'array'

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'array' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(array) sum_(sum) p(sum) factor(sum,array)]/p(array).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.FastSumOp.ArrayAverageConditional``1(System.Double,System.Collections.Generic.IList{MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian},``0)
member.summary: EP message to 'array'
member.param: Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of 'array' conditioned on the given values.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gamma
member.summary: A Gamma distribution on positive reals.

remarks.para: The distribution is p(x) = x^(a-1)*exp(-x*b)*b^a/Gamma(a). In this code, the a parameter is called the "Shape" and the b parameter is called the "Rate". The distribution is sometimes also parameterized by (shape,scale) where scale = 1/rate. The mean of the distribution is shape/rate and the variance is shape/rate^2.

Special cases: When the shape is 1 and rate is 0, the distribution is uniform. When the shape is infinity, the distribution is a point mass and the density is delta(x-Point) where the Point property gives the mean. When a <= 0 or b <= 0 the b^a/Gamma(a) term is dropped.

member.summary: Gets the variance - calculated as shape/rate^2
member.returns: Variance

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gamma.FromMeanAndMeanLog(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Constructs a Gamma distribution with the given mean and mean logarithm.
member.returns: A new Gamma distribution.
member.remarks: This function is equivalent to maximum-likelihood estimation of a Gamma distribution from data given by sufficient statistics. This function is significantly slower than the other constructors since it involves nonlinear optimization. The algorithm is a generalized Newton iteration, described in "Estimating a Gamma distribution" by T. Minka, 2002.

member.remarks: The distribution is p(x) = x^(a-1)*exp(-x*b)*b^a/Gamma(a). When a <= 0 or b <= 0 the b^a/Gamma(a) term is dropped. Thus if shape = 1 and rate = 0 the density is 1.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gamma.#ctor(System.Double,System.Double)

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath
member.summary: This class provides mathematical constants and special functions, analogous to System.Math. It cannot be instantiated and consists of static members only.

remarks.para: In order to provide the highest accuracy, some routines return their results in log form or logit form. These transformations expand the domain to cover the full range of double-precision values, ensuring all bits of the representation are utilized. A good example of this is the NormalCdf function, whose value lies between 0 and 1. Numbers between 0 and 1 use only a small fraction of the capacity of a double-precision number. The function NormalCdfLogit transforms the result p according to log(p/(1-p)), providing full use of the range from -Infinity to Infinity and (potentially) much higher precision.

To get maximal use out of these transformations, you want to stay in the expanded form as long as possible. Every time you transform into a smaller domain, you lose precision. Thus helper functions are provided which allow you to perform common tasks directly in the log form and logit form. For logs, you have addition. For logit, you have averaging.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.Gamma(System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluates Gamma(x), defined as the integral from 0 to x of t^(x-1)*exp(-t) dt.
member.returns: Gamma(x).
member.remarks: Uses the Lanczos approximation described in: A Precision Approximation of the Gamma Function, J. SIAM Numer. Anal. Ser. B 1: 86-96, 1964.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.GammaLn(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the natural logarithm of the Gamma function.
member.returns: ln(Gamma(x)).
member.remarks: This function provides higher accuracy than Math.Log(Gamma(x)), which may fail for large x.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.GammaLn(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the natural logarithm of the multivariate Gamma function.
member.returns: ln(Gamma_d(x))
member.remarks: The multivariate Gamma function is defined as Gamma_d(x) = pi^(d*(d-1)/4)*prod_(i=1..d) Gamma(x + (1-i)/2)

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.Digamma(System.Double)

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.Erfc(System.Double)

member.returns: The complementary error function at x.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.ErfcInv(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the inverse of the complementary error function, i.e. erfcinv(erfc(x)) == x.
member.returns: A number x such that erfc(x) == y.
member.remarks: This function uses a polynomial approximation together with one step of Halley's rational method.

member.returns: The cumulative Gaussian distribution at .

member.remarks: This function provides higher accuracy than Math.Log(NormalCdf(x)), which can fail for x < -7.

member.returns: ln(NormalCdf(x)/(1-NormalCdf(x))).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.NormalCdfInv(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the inverse of the cumulative Gaussian distribution, i.e. NormalCdf(NormalCdfInv(p)) == p. For example, NormalCdfInv(0.5) == 0. This is also known as the Gaussian quantile function.
member.returns: A number x such that NormalCdf(x) == p.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.NormalCdfMomentRatio(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes int_0^infinity t^n N(t;x,1) dt / (n! N(x;0,1))

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.NormalCdf(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the cumulative bivariate normal distribution.
member.remarks: The cumulative bivariate normal distribution is defined as int_(-inf)^x int_(-inf)^y N([x;y],[0;0],[1 r; r 1]) dx dy where N([x;y],[0;0],[1 r; r 1]) = exp(-0.5*(x^2+y^2-2*x*y*r)/(1-r^2))/(2*pi*sqrt(1-r^2)). The double integral is transformed into a single integral which is approximated by quadrature. For full details, see: "Numerical Computation of Rectangular Bivariate and Trivariate Normal and t Probabilities" Alan Genz, Statistics and Computing, 14 (2004), pp. 151-160 http://www.math.wsu.edu/faculty/genz/genzhome/research.html

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.NormalCdfLn(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the natural logarithm of the cumulative bivariate normal distribution.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.Logistic(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the logistic function 1/(1+exp(-x)).
member.param: Any real number from -Inf to Inf, or NaN.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.LogisticLn(System.Double)
member.summary: Compute the natural logarithm of the logistic function, i.e. -log(1+exp(-x)).
member.param: Any real number from -Inf to Inf, or NaN.
member.returns: -log(1+exp(-x)).
member.remarks: This function provides higher accuracy than a direct evaluation of -log(1+exp(-x)), which can fail for x < -50 and x > 36.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.Log1Plus(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the natural logarithm of 1+x.
member.param: A non-negative real number: 0 <= x <= Inf, or NaN.
member.returns: log(1+x), which is always >= 0.
member.remarks: This function provides higher accuracy than a direct evaluation of log(1+x), particularly when is small.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.Log1PlusExp(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes log(1 + exp(x)) to high accuracy.
member.param: Any real number from -Inf to Inf, or NaN.
member.returns: log(1+exp(x)), which is always >= 0.
member.remarks: This function provides higher accuracy than a direct evaluation of log(1+exp(x)), particularly when x < -36 or x > 50.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.Log1MinusExp(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes log(1 - exp(x)) to high accuracy.
member.param: A non-positive real number: -Inf <= x <= 0, or NaN.
member.returns: log(1-exp(x)), which is always <= 0.
member.remarks: This function provides higher accuracy than a direct evaluation of log(1-exp(x)), particularly when x < -7.5 or x > -1e-5.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.ExpMinus1(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the exponential of x and subtracts 1.
member.param: Any real number from -Inf to Inf, or NaN.
member.returns: exp(x)-1
member.remarks: This function is more accurate than a direct evaluation of exp(x)-1 when x is small. It is the inverse function to Log1Plus: ExpMinus1(Log1Plus(x)) == x.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.LogExpMinus1(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes log(exp(x)-1) for non-negative x.
member.param: A non-negative real number: 0 <= x <= Inf, or NaN.
member.remarks: This function is more accurate than a direct evaluation of log(exp(x)-1) when x < 1e-3 or x > 50. It is the inverse function to Log1PlusExp: LogExpMinus1(Log1PlusExp(x)) == x.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.LogSumExp(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes log(exp(x) + exp(y)) to high accuracy.
member.param: Any real number from -Inf to Inf, or NaN.
Any real number from -Inf to Inf, or NaN.
member.returns: log(exp(x)+exp(y)), which is always >= max(x,y).
member.remarks: This function provides higher accuracy than a direct evaluation of log(exp(x)+exp(y)).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.LogSumExp(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double})
member.summary: Returns the log of the sum of exponentials of a list of doubles

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.LogSumExpSparse(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double})
member.summary: Returns the log of the sum of exponentials of a list of doubles

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.DiffLogSumExp(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes log(exp(x)+exp(a))-log(exp(x)+exp(b)) to high accuracy.
member.param: Any real number from -Inf to Inf, or NaN.
member.returns: log(exp(x)+exp(a))-log(exp(x)+exp(b))
member.remarks: This function provides higher accuracy than a direct evaluation of LogSumExp(x,a)-LogSumExp(x,b), particularly when x is large.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.Logit(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the log-odds function log(p/(1-p)).
member.returns: log(p/(1-p))
member.remarks: This function is the inverse of the logistic function, i.e. Logistic(Logit(p)) == p.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.LogitFromLog(System.Double)
member.summary: Compute log(p/(1-p)) from log(p).
member.returns: log(exp(logp)/(1-exp(logp))) = -log(exp(-logp)-1).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.Softmax(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Exponentiate array elements and normalize to sum to 1.
member.returns: A Vector p where p[k] = exp(x[k])/sum_j exp(x[j])
member.remarks: Sparse lists and vectors are handled efficiently

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.Log1PlusExpGaussian(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluates E[log(1+exp(x))] under a Gaussian distribution with specified mean and variance.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.LogisticGaussian(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculate sigma(m,v) = \int N(x;m,v) logistic(x) dx
member.returns: The value of this special function.

remarks.para: Note 1-LogisticGaussian(m,v) = LogisticGaussian(-m,v) which is more accurate.

For large v we can use the big v approximation \sigma(m,v)=normcdf(m/sqrt(v+pi^2/3)). For small and moderate v we use Gauss-Hermite quadrature. For moderate v we first find the mode of the (log concave) function since this may be quite far from m.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.LogisticGaussianDerivative(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculate \sigma'(m,v)=\int N(x;m,v)logistic'(x) dx
member.returns: The value of this special function.

remarks.para: For large v we can use the big v approximation \sigma'(m,v)=N(m,0,v+pi^2/3). For small and moderate v we use Gauss-Hermite quadrature. For moderate v we first find the mode of the (log concave) function since this may be quite far from m.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.MMath.LogisticGaussianDerivative2(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculate \sigma''(m,v)=\int N(x;m,v)logistic''(x) dx
member.returns: The value of this special function.

remarks.para: For large v we can use the big v approximation \sigma'(m,v)=-m/(v+pi^2/3)*N(m,0,v+pi^2/3). For small and moderate v we use Gauss-Hermite quadrature. The function is multimodal so mode finding is difficult and probably won't help.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.LogisticOp.XAverageConditional(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Beta,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian)
member.summary: EP message to 'x'
member.param: Incoming message from 'logistic'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from 'x'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the 'x' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'x' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(x) sum_(logistic) p(logistic) factor(logistic,x)]/p(x).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.LogisticOp.AverageLogFactor(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Beta,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Beta)
member.summary: Evidence message for VMP
member.returns: Zero

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(factor(logistic,x)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for VMP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.LogisticOp.LogisticAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian)
member.summary: VMP message to 'logistic'
member.param: Incoming message from 'x'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'logistic' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'logistic' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[sum_(x) p(x) factor(logistic,x)].

member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'x' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of 'x' with 'logistic' integrated out. The formula is sum_logistic p(logistic) factor(logistic,x).

member.summary: EP message to 'factor'

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.VectorGaussian
member.summary: Represents a multivariate Gaussian distribution.

remarks.para: The distribution is parameterized by MeanTimesPrecision and Precision. Precision is the inverse of the variance, so a Gaussian with mean m and variance v is represented as Precision = inv(v), MeanTimesPrecision = inv(v)*m.

Some special cases: If the precision is zero, then the distribution is uniform. If the precision is infinite along the diagonal, then the distribution is a point mass. The Point property gives the location of the point mass. If precision[i,i] is infinite, then the distribution is a point mass along dimension i. Point[i] gives the mean. The rest of the row and column of precision must be zero.

The formula for the distribution is: N(x;m,v) = |2*pi*v|^(-d/2) * exp(-0.5 (x-m)' inv(v) (x-m)). When v=0, this reduces to delta(x-m). When v=infinity, the density is redefined to be 1. When v is singular, the density is redefined to be exp(-0.5 x' inv(v) x + x' inv(v) m), i.e. we drop the terms |2*pi*v|^(-d/2) * exp(-0.5 m' inv(v) m).

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Dirichlet
member.summary: A Dirichlet distribution on probability vectors.

remarks.para: The Dirichlet is a distribution on probability vectors. The formula for the distribution is p(x) = (Gamma(a)/prod_i Gamma(b_i)) prod_i x_i^{b_i-1} subject to the constraints x_i >= 0 and sum_i x_i = 1. The parameter a is the "total pseudo-count" and is shorthand for sum_i b_i. The vector b contains the pseudo-counts for each case i. The vector b can be sparse or dense; in many cases it is useful to give it a specification of .

The distribution is represented by the pair (TotalCount, PseudoCount). If TotalCount is infinity, the distribution is a point mass. The Point property gives the mean. Otherwise TotalCount is always equal to PseudoCount.Sum(). If distribution is uniform when all PseudoCounts = 1. If any PseudoCount <= 0, the distribution is improper. In this case, the density is redefined to not include the Gamma terms, i.e. there is no normalizer.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Dirichlet.TotalCount
member.summary: Gets the total count. If infinite, the distribution is a point mass. Otherwise, this is the sum of pseudo-counts

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Dirichlet.PseudoCount
member.summary: Vector of pseudo-counts

member.summary: Whether the the distribution is proprer or not. It is proper if all pseudo-counts are > 0.
member.returns: true if proper, false otherwise

member.summary: Gets the variance var(p) = m*(1-m)/(1+s)
member.returns: The variance

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Dirichlet.GetMeanAndVariance(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector)
member.summary: Gets the mean E(p) = m/s and variance var(p) = m*(1-m)/(1+s)

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Dirichlet.SetMeanAndMeanSquare(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector)
member.summary: Sets the mean, and sets the precision to best match the given mean-squares.
member.param: Desired mean in each dimension. Must be in [0,1] and sum to 1.
Desired meanSquare in each dimension. Must be in [0,1].
member.remarks: The resulting distribution will have the given mean but will only approximately match the meanSquare, since the Dirichlet does not have enough parameters. The moment matching formula comes from: "Expectation-Propagation for the Generative Aspect Model", Thomas Minka and John Lafferty, Proceedings of the 18th Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence, pp. 352-359, 2002 http://research.microsoft.com/~minka/papers/aspect/

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Dirichlet.SetMeanAndVariance(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector)
member.summary: Sets the mean, and sets the precision to best match the given variances.
member.param: Desired mean in each dimension. Must be in [0,1] and sum to 1.
Desired variance in each dimension. Must be non-negative.
member.remarks: The resulting distribution will have the given mean but will only approximately match the variance, since the Dirichlet does not have enough parameters. The moment matching formula comes from: "Expectation-Propagation for the Generative Aspect Model", Thomas Minka and John Lafferty, Proceedings of the 18th Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence, pp. 352-359, 2002 http://research.microsoft.com/~minka/papers/aspect/

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Dirichlet.FromMeanLog(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector)
member.summary: Create a Dirichlet distribution with the given expected logarithms.
member.param: Desired expectation E[log(pk)] for each k.
member.returns: A new Dirichlet where GetMeanLog == meanLog
member.remarks: This function is equivalent to maximum-likelihood estimation of a Dirichlet distribution from data given by sufficient statistics. This function is significantly slower than the other constructors since it involves nonlinear optimization. Uses the Newton algorithm described in "Estimating a Dirichlet distribution" by T. Minka, 2000.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Dirichlet.SetMeanLog(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector)
member.summary: Set the Dirichlet parameters to produce the given expected logarithms.
member.param: Desired expectation E[log(pk)] for each k.
member.remarks: This function is equivalent to maximum-likelihood estimation of a Dirichlet distribution from data given by sufficient statistics. This function is significantly slower than the other setters since it involves nonlinear optimization. Uses the Newton algorithm described in "Estimating a Dirichlet distribution" by T. Minka, 2000.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BooleanOrOp.LogAverageFactor(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(or) p(or) factor(or,a,b)).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BooleanOrOp.OrAverageConditional(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli)
member.summary: EP message to 'or'
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the 'or' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'or' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(or) sum_(a,b) p(a,b) factor(or,a,b)]/p(or).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BooleanOrOp.OrAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli)
member.summary: VMP message to 'or'
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'or' argument

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BooleanOrOp.OrAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli,System.Boolean)
member.summary: VMP message to 'or'
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'or' argument

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BooleanOrOp.AAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli)
member.summary: VMP message to 'a'
member.param: Incoming message from 'or'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'a' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'a'. Because the factor is deterministic, 'or' is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(b) p(b) log(sum_or p(or) factor(or,a,b))).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BooleanOrOp.AAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli,System.Boolean)

member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'a' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of 'a' with 'or' integrated out. The formula is sum_or p(or) factor(or,a,b).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.GammaFromShapeAndRateOp.CalculateDerivatives(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gamma)
member.summary: Calculate derivatives of \int G(x;a,b) LogGamma(x) dx wrt (a,b)
member.returns: A 2-vector containing derivatives of \int G(x;a,b) LogGamma(x) dx wrt (a,b).

remarks.para: Calculates expectations in x=log(s) space using Gauss-Hermite quadrature. For each integral the behaviour as x->0 is subtracted from the integrand before performing quadrature to remove the singularity there.

member.summary: VMP message to 'B'
member.param: Incoming message from 'Sum'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.SumWhereOp.BAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.DistributionStructArray{MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli,System.Boolean},MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.VectorGaussian)
member.summary: VMP message to 'B'
member.param: Incoming message from 'Sum'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'B'. Because the factor is deterministic, 'Sum' is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(A) p(A) log(sum_Sum p(Sum) factor(Sum,A,B))).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.IntCasesOp.CasesAverageConditional``1(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete,``0)
member.summary: EP message to 'casesInt'.
member.param: Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the integral of the factor times incoming messages, over all arguments except 'casesInt'. The formula is int f(casesInt,x) q(x) dx where x = (i).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.IntCasesOp.IAverageConditional(System.Collections.Generic.IList{MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli},MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: EP message to 'i'.
member.param: Incoming message from 'casesInt'. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the integral of the factor times incoming messages, over all arguments except 'i'. The formula is int f(i,x) q(x) dx where x = (casesInt).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.IntCasesOp.LogEvidenceRatio(System.Collections.Generic.IList{MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli},MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.IntCasesOp.LogEvidenceRatio(System.Collections.Generic.IList{MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli},System.Int32)
member.summary: Evidence message for Gibbs.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.IntCasesOp.CasesAverageLogarithm``1(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete,``0)
member.summary: VMP message to 'casesInt'.
member.param: Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the integral of the log-factor times incoming messages, over all arguments except 'casesInt'. The formula is int log(f(casesInt,x)) q(x) dx where x = (i).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.IntCasesOp.IAverageLogarithm(System.Collections.Generic.IList{MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli},MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: VMP message to 'i'.
member.param: Incoming message from 'casesInt'. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the integral of the log-factor times incoming messages, over all arguments except 'i'. The formula is int log(f(i,x)) q(x) dx where x = (casesInt).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.IntCasesOp.AverageLogFactor(System.Collections.Generic.IList{MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli},MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: Evidence message for VMP.
member.param: Incoming message from 'casesInt'. Must be a proper distribution. If all elements are uniform, the result will be uniform.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is int log(f(x)) q(x) dx where x = (casesInt,i).

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.OffsetCopyOp`1
member.summary: Provides outgoing messages for , given random arguments to the function.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.OffsetCopyOp`1.LogAverageFactor
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(factor(OffsetCopy,value)).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.OffsetCopyOp`1.LogEvidenceRatio``1(``0)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(OffsetCopy) p(OffsetCopy) factor(OffsetCopy,value) / sum_OffsetCopy p(OffsetCopy) messageTo(OffsetCopy)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.OffsetCopyOp`1.LogEvidenceRatio``1(`0,``0)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(value) p(value) factor(OffsetCopy,value)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.OffsetCopyOp`1.InputAverageConditional``2(``1,``0)
member.summary: EP message to 'value'
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the 'value' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'value' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(value) sum_(OffsetCopy) p(OffsetCopy) factor(OffsetCopy,value)]/p(value).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.OffsetCopyOp`1.InputAverageConditional``1(``0,`0,``0)
member.summary: EP message to 'value'
member.param: Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of 'value' conditioned on the given values.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.OffsetCopyOp`1.OutputAverageConditional``2(``1,``0)
member.summary: EP message to 'OffsetCopy'
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the 'OffsetCopy' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'OffsetCopy' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(OffsetCopy) sum_(value) p(value) factor(OffsetCopy,value)]/p(OffsetCopy).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.OffsetCopyOp`1.AverageLogFactor
member.summary: Evidence message for VMP
member.returns: Zero

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(factor(OffsetCopy,value)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for VMP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.OffsetCopyOp`1.InputAverageLogarithm``2(``1,``0)
member.summary: VMP message to 'value'
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'value' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of 'value' with 'OffsetCopy' integrated out. The formula is sum_OffsetCopy p(OffsetCopy) factor(OffsetCopy,value).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.OffsetCopyOp`1.InputAverageLogarithm``1(``0,`0,``0)
member.summary: VMP message to 'value'
member.param: Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of 'value' conditioned on the given values.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.OffsetCopyOp`1.OutputAverageLogarithm``2(``1,``0)
member.summary: VMP message to 'OffsetCopy'
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'OffsetCopy' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'OffsetCopy' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[sum_(value) p(value) factor(OffsetCopy,value)].

member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(b) p(b) factor(and,a,b)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BooleanAndOp.AverageLogFactor
member.summary: Evidence message for VMP.
member.returns: Zero

remarks.para: In Variational Message Passing, the evidence contribution of a deterministic factor is zero.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BooleanAndOp.AndAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli)
member.summary: VMP message to 'and'.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'and' argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'and' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[sum_(a,b) p(a,b) factor(and,a,b)].

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BooleanAndOp.AndAverageLogarithm(System.Boolean,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli)
member.summary: VMP message to 'and'.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'and' argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the integral of the log-factor times incoming messages, over all arguments except 'and'. The formula is int log(f(and,x)) q(x) dx where x = (a,b).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BooleanAndOp.AndAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli,System.Boolean)

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of 'precision' conditioned on the given values.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.GaussianOp.SampleAverageConditional(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,System.Double)
member.summary: EP message to 'sample'
member.param: Incoming message from 'mean'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the 'sample' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'sample' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(sample) sum_(mean) p(mean) factor(sample,mean,precision)]/p(sample).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.GaussianOp.LogEvidenceRatio(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(factor(sample,mean,precision)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.GaussianOp.LogEvidenceRatio(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,System.Double)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(sample,mean) p(sample,mean) factor(sample,mean,precision) / sum_sample p(sample) messageTo(sample)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.summary: VMP message to 'sample'
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'sample' argument

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.GaussianOp.SampleAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,System.Double)
member.summary: VMP message to 'sample'
member.param: Incoming message from 'mean'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'sample' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'sample'. The formula is exp(sum_(mean) p(mean) log(factor(sample,mean,precision))).

member.param: Incoming message from 'totalCount'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'prob' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'prob'. The formula is exp(sum_(totalCount) p(totalCount) log(factor(prob,mean,totalCount))).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.DirichletOp.TotalCountAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gamma,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gamma)
member.summary: VMP message to 'totalCount'
member.param: Incoming message from 'totalCount'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'totalCount' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of 'totalCount' conditioned on the given values.
The outgoing message here would not be Dirichlet distributed, so we use Nonconjugate VMP, which sends the approximate factor ensuring the gradient of the KL wrt to the variational parameters match.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.DirichletOp.MeanMessageExpectations(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gamma,System.Double[]@,System.Double[]@,System.Double[]@)
member.summary: Perform the quadrature required for the Nonconjugate VMP message to 'mean'
member.param: Array to be filled with E[LogGamma(s*m_k)].
Array to be filled with E[Log(m_k)*LogGamma(s*m_k)].
Array to be filled with E[Log(1-m_k)*LogGamma(s*m_k)].

remarks.para: All three arrays are calculated simultaneously for efficiency. The quadrature over 'totalCount' (which is Gamma-distributed) is peformed by a change of variable x=log(s) followed by Gauss-Hermite quadrature. The quadrature over m is performed using Gauss-Legendre.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.DirichletOp.TotalCountMessageExpectations(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gamma,System.Double[]@,System.Double[]@,System.Double[]@)
member.summary: Perform the quadrature required for the Nonconjugate VMP message to 'totalCount'
member.param: Array to be filled with E[LogGamma(s*m_k)].
Array to be filled with E[Log(s)*LogGamma(s*m_k)].
Array to be filled with E[s*m_k*Digamma(s*m_k)].

remarks.para: All three arrays are calculated simultaneously for efficiency. The quadrature over 'totalCount' (which is Gamma-distributed) is peformed by a change of variable x=log(s) followed by Gauss-Hermite quadrature. The quadrature over m is performed using Gauss-Legendre.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.DirichletOp.EvidenceMessageExpectations(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Dirichlet,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gamma)
member.summary: Perform the quadrature required for the VMP evidence message
member.returns: Vector of E[ LogGamma(s*m_k)].

remarks.para: The quadrature over 'totalCount' (which is Gamma-distributed) is peformed by a change of variable x=log(s) followed by Gauss-Hermite quadrature. The quadrature over m is performed using Gauss-Legendre.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.DirichletOp.ProbAverageConditional(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Dirichlet,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gamma)
member.summary: EP message to 'prob'
member.param: Incoming message from 'mean'. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from 'totalCount'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the 'prob' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'prob' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(prob) sum_(mean,totalCount) p(mean,totalCount) factor(prob,mean,totalCount)]/p(prob).

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Poisson
member.summary: A Poisson distribution over the integers [0,infinity).

remarks.para: The Poisson is often used as a distribution on counts. The formula for the distribution is p(x) = rate^x exp(-rate) / x! where rate is the rate parameter. In this implementation, we use a generalization called the Conway-Maxwell Poisson or "Com-Poisson", which has an extra precision parameter nu. The formula for the distribution is p(x) =propto rate^x / x!^nu. With this extension, we can represent a uniform distribution via (rate=1,nu=0) and a point mass via rate=0 or nu=infinity. This family is closed under multiplication, while the standard Poisson is not.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Poisson.Rate
member.summary: The rate parameter of the COM-Poisson distribution, always >= 0.
member.remarks: The natural parameter of the distribution is log(rate). However, since rate remains >= 0 under multiplication, there is no harm in using rate as the parameter.

member.summary: Asks whether this instance is proper or not. A COM-Poisson distribution is proper if Rate >= 0 and (Precision > 0 or (Precision == 0 and Rate < 1)).
member.returns: True if proper, false otherwise

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Poisson.GetLogProb(System.Int32)
member.summary: Evaluates the log of of the density function of this COM-Poisson at the given value
member.param: The value at which to calculate the density
member.returns: log p(x=value)
member.remarks: The formula for the distribution is p(x) = rate^x exp(-rate) / x! when nu=1. In the general case, it is p(x) =propto rate^x / x!^nu. If the distribution is improper, the normalizer is omitted.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.DenseVector.MaxDiff(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector)
member.summary: Returns the maximum absolute difference between this vector and another vector.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.DenseVector.MaxDiff(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.DenseVector)
member.summary: Returns the maximum absolute difference between this dense vector and another dense vector.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.DenseVector.MaxDiff(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.Vector,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the maximum relative difference between this vector and another.
member.param: An offset to avoid division by zero.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])/(abs(this[i]) + rel)). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.DenseVector.MaxDiff(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Maths.DenseVector,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the maximum relative difference between this dense vector and another.
member.param: An offset to avoid division by zero.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])/(abs(this[i]) + rel)). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.remarks: this is used as the right-hand side vector b, and it also receives the solution. Throws an exception if is singular.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.Replicate2BufferOp.DefAverageConditional``1(System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0},``0)
member.summary: EP message to 'Def'
member.param: Incoming message from 'Uses'. Must be a proper distribution. If all elements are uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'Def' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(Def) sum_(Uses) p(Uses) factor(Uses,Def,Marginal)]/p(Def).

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.ReplicateOp
member.summary: Messages from random variables that are defined by deterministic factors.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.ReplicateOp.LogAverageFactor
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(factor(Uses,Def,Marginal)).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.ReplicateOp.LogEvidenceRatio``1(System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0},``0,System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0})
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.param: Incoming message from 'Uses'. Must be a proper distribution. If all elements are uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(Uses,Def) p(Uses,Def) factor(Uses,Def,Marginal) / sum_Uses p(Uses) messageTo(Uses)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.ReplicateOp.AverageLogFactor
member.summary: Evidence message for VMP
member.returns: Zero

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(factor(Uses,Def,Marginal)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for VMP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.ReplicateOp.MarginalAverageLogarithm``2(``1,``0)
member.summary: VMP message to 'Marginal'
member.param: Incoming message from 'Def'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'Marginal'. The formula is exp(sum_(Def) p(Def) log(factor(Uses,Def,Marginal))).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.ReplicateOp.UsesAverageLogarithm``2(``1,System.Int32,``0)

member.param: Index of the 'Uses' array for which a message is desired
Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'Uses' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[sum_(Def) p(Def) factor(Uses,Def,Marginal)].

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.GaussianProductOp.ProductAverageConditional(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian)
member.summary: EP message to 'product'
member.param: Incoming message from 'a'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from 'b'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the 'product' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'product' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(product) sum_(a,b) p(a,b) factor(product,a,b)]/p(product).

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.GaussianProductOp_SHG09
member.summary: This class allows EP to process the product factor as if running VMP, as required by Stern's algorithm.
member.remarks: This algorithm comes from "Matchbox: Large Scale Online Bayesian Recommendations" by David Stern, Ralf Herbrich, and Thore Graepel, WWW 2009.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(ratio,a) p(ratio,a) factor(ratio,a,b) / sum_ratio p(ratio) messageTo(ratio)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.GaussianProductVmpOp.ProductAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian)
member.summary: VMP message to 'product'
member.param: Incoming message from 'a'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from 'b'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'product' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'product' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[sum_(a,b) p(a,b) factor(product,a,b)].

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.GaussianProductVmpOp.ProductAverageLogarithm(System.Double,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian)
member.summary: VMP message to 'product'
member.param: Incoming message from 'b'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'product' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'product' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[sum_(b) p(b) factor(product,a,b)].

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.GaussianProductVmpOp.ProductAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,System.Double)
member.summary: VMP message to 'product'
member.param: Incoming message from 'a'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'product' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'product' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[sum_(a) p(a) factor(product,a,b)].

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.GaussianProductVmpOp.AAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian)
member.summary: VMP message to 'a'
member.param: Incoming message from 'product'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from 'b'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'a' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'a'. Because the factor is deterministic, 'product' is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(b) p(b) log(sum_product p(product) factor(product,a,b))).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.GaussianProductVmpOp.AAverageLogarithm(System.Double,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Gaussian)

member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'a' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'a'. The formula is exp(sum_(b) p(b) log(factor(product,a,b))).

member.param: Incoming message from 'isGreaterThan'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of 'b' with 'isGreaterThan' integrated out. The formula is sum_isGreaterThan p(isGreaterThan) factor(isGreaterThan,a,b).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.IsGreaterThanOp.AverageLogFactor(System.Boolean,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: Evidence message for VMP
member.returns: Zero

remarks.para: In Variational Message Passing, the evidence contribution of a deterministic factor is zero. Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for VMP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.IsGreaterThanOp.AverageLogFactor(System.Boolean,System.Int32,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: Evidence message for VMP
member.returns: Zero

remarks.para: In Variational Message Passing, the evidence contribution of a deterministic factor is zero. Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for VMP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.IsGreaterThanOp.AverageLogFactor(System.Boolean,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete,System.Int32)
member.summary: Evidence message for VMP
member.returns: Zero

remarks.para: In Variational Message Passing, the evidence contribution of a deterministic factor is zero. Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for VMP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.IsGreaterThanOp.AAverageLogarithm(System.Boolean,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: VMP message to 'a'
member.param: Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'a'. The formula is exp(sum_(b) p(b) log(factor(isGreaterThan,a,b))).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.IsGreaterThanOp.BAverageLogarithm(System.Boolean,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: VMP message to 'b'
member.param: Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'b'. The formula is exp(sum_(a) p(a) log(factor(isGreaterThan,a,b))).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.IsGreaterThanOp.AAverageLogarithm(System.Boolean,System.Int32,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: VMP message to 'a'
member.param: Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of 'a' conditioned on the given values.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.GetItemsOp`1.LogAverageFactor``1(System.Collections.Generic.IList{`0},System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0},System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Int32})
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(items,array) p(items,array) factor(items,array,indices)).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.GetItemsOp`1.LogEvidenceRatio``1(System.Collections.Generic.IList{`0},System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0},System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Int32})
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(items,array) p(items,array) factor(items,array,indices) / sum_items p(items) messageTo(items)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.GetItemsOp`1.ArrayAverageConditional``2(System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0},System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Int32},``1)

member.param: Incoming message from 'items'. Must be a proper distribution. If all elements are uniform, the result will be uniform.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'array' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(array) sum_(items) p(items) factor(items,array,indices)]/p(array).
