member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BinomialOp
member.summary: Provides outgoing messages for , given random arguments to the function.
member.remarks: The factor is f(sample,n,p) = choose(n,sample) p^sample (1-p)^(n-sample)

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BinomialOp.LogAverageFactor(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(sample) p(sample) factor(sample,trialCount,p)).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BinomialOp.LogAverageFactor(System.Int32,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(factor(sample,trialCount,p)).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BinomialOp.LogAverageFactor(System.Int32,System.Double,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(trialCount) p(trialCount) factor(sample,trialCount,p)).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BinomialOp.LogAverageFactor(System.Int32,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Beta,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(p,trialCount) p(p,trialCount) factor(sample,trialCount,p)).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BinomialOp.LogAverageFactor(System.Int32,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Beta,System.Int32)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(p) p(p) factor(sample,trialCount,p)).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BinomialOp.LogEvidenceRatio(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(sample) p(sample) factor(sample,trialCount,p) / sum_sample p(sample) messageTo(sample)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BinomialOp.LogEvidenceRatio(System.Int32,System.Double,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(trialCount) p(trialCount) factor(sample,trialCount,p)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BinomialOp.SampleAverageConditional(System.Double,System.Int32,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: EP message to 'sample'
member.param: Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of 'sample' conditioned on the given values.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BinomialOp.SampleAverageConditional(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Beta,System.Int32,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: EP message to 'sample'
member.param: Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'sample' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(sample) sum_(p) p(p) factor(sample,trialCount,p)]/p(sample).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BinomialOp.SampleAverageConditional(System.Double,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: EP message to 'sample'
member.param: Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'sample' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(sample) sum_(trialCount) p(trialCount) factor(sample,trialCount,p)]/p(sample).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BinomialOp.SampleAverageConditional(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Beta,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: EP message to 'sample'
member.param: Modified to contain the outgoing message

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'sample' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(sample) sum_(p,trialCount) p(p,trialCount) factor(sample,trialCount,p)]/p(sample).

member.summary: VMP message to 'p'

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of 'p' conditioned on the given values.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BinomialOp.PAverageLogarithm(System.Int32,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: VMP message to 'p'
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'p' argument

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'p'. The formula is exp(sum_(trialCount) p(trialCount) log(factor(sample,trialCount,p))).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BinomialOp.PAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete,System.Int32)
member.summary: VMP message to 'p'

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'p'. The formula is exp(sum_(sample) p(sample) log(factor(sample,trialCount,p))).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BinomialOp.PAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: VMP message to 'p'

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BooleanAreEqualOp.AreEqualAverageConditional(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli)
member.summary: EP message to 'areEqual'.
member.param: Incoming message from 'a'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from 'b'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the 'areEqual' argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the integral of the factor times incoming messages, over all arguments except 'areEqual'. The formula is int f(areEqual,x) q(x) dx where x = (a,b).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BooleanAreEqualOp.AreEqualAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli)
member.summary: VMP message to 'areEqual'.
member.param: Incoming message from 'a'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from 'b'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'areEqual' argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of 'areEqual' as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[sum_(a,b) p(a,b) factor(areEqual,a,b)].

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.BooleanAreEqualOp.AreEqualAverageLogarithm(System.Boolean,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli)
member.summary: VMP message to 'areEqual'.
member.param: Incoming message from 'b'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the 'areEqual' argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the integral of the log-factor times incoming messages, over all arguments except 'areEqual'. The formula is int log(f(areEqual,x)) q(x) dx where x = (a,b).

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Factors.DiscreteAreEqualOp.AAverageLogarithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Bernoulli,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: VMP message to 'a'.
member.param: Incoming message from 'areEqual'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except 'a'. Because the factor is deterministic, 'areEqual' is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(b) p(b) log(sum_areEqual p(areEqual) factor(areEqual,a,b))).

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.WrappedGaussian
member.summary: A Gaussian distribution on a periodic domain, such as angles between 0 and 2*pi.
member.remarks: The distribution is represented by a unwrapped Gaussian and a period length L. To get the wrapped density, the unwrapped density is summed over all shifts by L, i.e. p(x) = sum_k N(x + Lk; m, v) over all integers k The wrapped density is automatically normalized over the range [0,L) because it simply moves the probability mass that was previously distributed over the real line to all lie in the interval [0,L).

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Beta
member.summary: A Beta distribution over the interval [0,1].

remarks.para: The Beta is often used as a distribution on probability values. The formula for the distribution is p(x) = (Gamma(trueCount+falseCount)/Gamma(trueCount)/Gamma(falseCount)) x^{trueCount-1} (1-x)^(falseCount-1) subject to the constraint 0 <= x <= 1.

If trueCount = falseCount = 1, the distribution is uniform. If falseCount = infinity, the distribution is redefined to be a point mass on trueCount. When trueCount <= 0 or falseCount <= 0, the distribution is improper. In this case, the density is redefined to not include the Gamma terms, i.e. there is no normalizer.

member.summary: Whether the distribution is proper or not. It is improper when trueCount <= 0 or falseCount <= 0 in which case it cannot be normalised
member.returns: true if proper, false otherwise

member.remarks: The result must be between 0 and 1.

member.summary: Creates a Beta distribution with the given parameters.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Distributions.Beta.FromMeanLogs(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Constructs a Beta distribution with the given E[log(p)] and E[log(1-p)].
member.returns: A new Beta distribution.
member.remarks: This function is equivalent to maximum-likelihood estimation of a Beta distribution from data given by sufficient statistics. So we want to maximize (a-1)eLogP + (b-1)eLogOneMinusP + Gamma(a+b) - Gamma(a) - Gamma(b) with respect to a, b where a=trueCount, b=falseCount. This function is significantly slower than the other constructors since it involves nonlinear optimization.
